awd_titl_txt: Mapping the Instabilities of Massive Stars
awd_abstract_narration:
A plot of luminosity versus temperature for stars, known as the Hertzsprung-Russell (HR) diagram, has proven invaluable in our understanding of the stars.  A star's age and its mass determine its position on such a diagram.  At specific periods during a star's life, it may pulsate---actually get larger and smaller---as gas pressure outward and gravity inward are not quite in balance.  This project aims to investigate the processes inside pulsating hot, massive stars.  The investigator will use theory and numerical modeling to create a "map" on the HR diagram describing what might be going on inside stars for each combination of temperature and luminosity.  The results will be made available to the public via a web portal, in addition to publication of results in the refereed literature.  A female graduate student, already well along in her studies, will complete her PhD thesis with this funding.

Once stars evolve past the main sequence of the HR diagram, they can undergo many episodes of pulsation.  Cepheid variables are the best known and understood; they populate an area of the HR diagram known as the instability strip.  The investigator describes many other instability strips and makes the case for other causes of instability in stars more massive than the classical Cepheids.  For example, in addition to the radially symmetric pulsations of Cepheids, pulsation-rotation interactions and non-adiabatic pulsation are considered.  The work will involve modifications to the MESA and GYRE computer codes, which the PI has developed.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we built the tools necessary to explore instabilities
of massive stars, and then applied these tools to create the first
extensive and detailed instability maps.

So-called "massive" stars, those with masses of ten or more times the
Sun, are a 'noisy minority' in galaxy populations; they account for
only a small fraction of the stellar mass, but they emit most of the
light and other radiation permeating their host galaxies, and through
the supernova explosions at the end of their lives, they are key
drivers of galactic chemical evolution. Even before these dramatic
finales, however, massive stars are subject to a variety of
instabilities (spontaneous departures from static equilibrium) which
can shape their structure and subsequent evolution.

In the early stages of the project, we worked on improving two
important community tools --- MESA & GYRE --- for simulating massive
stars and their instabilities. MESA (Modules for Experiments in
Stellar Astrophysics) is an open-source software instrument for
building and evolving stellar models across the full mass range. We
contributed a number of significant improvements toward MESA, in
particular relating to the placement of convection-zone boundaries,
the modeling of atmospheric surface layers, and the software
infrastructure that supports the MESA ecosystem. GYRE is an
open-source software instrument for simulating the oscillations and
instabilities of input stellar models. Together with many other
usability enhancements, we implemented a new 'contour' method in GYRE,
allowing it to uncover fast-growing instabilities that traditional
methods miss.

In the later stages of the project, we applied MESA to construct grids
of stellar models, extending up to 150 times the mass of the Sun. We
then used GYRE to explore the instabilities of these models. We found
that radial-mode instabilities continue all the way up to the upper
mass limit of our grids; that the growth rates of instabilities
increases toward larger masses; and that these growth rates are
largest along ridges parallel to the zero-age main sequence line. We
also demonstrated that the contour method is an extremely robust and
effective approach for exploring instabilities across large grids of
stellar models.

Scientific merit:

The project leveraged recent advances in computational infrastructure
to explore massive-star instabilities at a level of detail never
before achievable. It came during an unprecedented expansion in
observing facilities which are revealing a rich phenomenology of
massive-star variability. The novel improvements to the GYRE software
instrument, made during the project, further cement its status as
*the* tool for studying stellar instabilities. Through publication of
the instability strips, and through the ongoing open-source
availability of the MESA and GYRE instruments, dividends of the
project are returned to the wider astronomical community.

Broader impacts:

The project has provided new views of the instabilities experienced by
massive stars throughout their lifetimes. It has supported the
participation of underrepresented groups in the field of computational
astrophysics. It has generated community resources for simulating and
interpreting observations of massive star variability. It has provided
multidisciplinary training in high performance computing, data
science, visualization, and development of open source software.
